bibl.title: Letter from Felipe Carbonell to the President of the Lion's Club of Havana, the Minister of Public Health, and the President of the Academy of Sciences, January 1952

div1.p: Carbonell describes Hench's investigations into the yellow fever experiments and the actual location of Camp Lazear. He praises Hench as a physician and a friend while advocating the support of Hench's plans by the Cuban government.

div1.head: Letter from Felipe Carbonell to the President of the Lion's Club of Havana, the Minister of Public Health, and the President of the Academy of Sciences, January 1952
div1.opener:
Mr. President of the Lion's Club of Havana.
Mr. Minister of the Public Health.
Mr. President of the Academy of Sciences.
Gentlemen:
div1.p:
On June 2nd. - 1941, at the unveiling of “The Conquerors of Ye-
llow Fever”, painted by the american artist Dean Cornwell, Dr.
Philip S. Hench, of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn. made an
explanatory speech of the painting. This speech was published
in one of the Proceedings edited weekly by the Clinic and also
in the panphlet that I have the pleasure of offering you.
Dr Carbonell

It is easy to explain why Dr. Hench was chosen to do that work.
To that purpose we are going to read an article that we broadcasted
on January 16th-1942, through the Station of Brothers William
and Manuel Salas who courteously offered it.
The article reads as follows:

“Leaving aside the scientific discussions that alwayas kept alive
the question of the conquest of Yellow Fever, we can assure that
the historical ‘caseta’, (barrack) of Camp Lazear was sunken in the
dark clouds of oblivion until our times when it is rented to a
family who actually lives there.

It was believed that Camp Lazear was located at the place where
for a long time, a hospital dedicated to yellow fever patients was
located, right by the tracks of the railroad that from Quemados de
Marianao goes to Marianao Beach. What was the cause of this confu-
sion? We have to confess that we don't know it. But if we consider
that when Dr. Lazear became ill of the cruel sickness that he was in-
vestigating, he was taken to said hospital where he finally died,
we can blame to this fact the completely or in part, the error
committed.

A tree surounded by a fence, and we have been informed that there
existed also a small memorial, is the place that we are talking
about.

That was the situation when Dr. Philip S. Hench arrived at Havana
with the purpose of solving this question. It was this distinguished
american phisician, in honor to truth, who located and identified
Camp Lazear. Dr. Hench, with the advise of those who had been there
while the experiments took place, perusing photographs and documents
-2-
including the rent receipts, stablished beyond doubt, the identity
and site of the caseta.

On other hand...What is Camp Lazear?. We'll explain it in a few
words.

After Lazear's death and having the Comission in its hands enough
details, united to those most valuable that appeared in Lazear's
note-book found in his uniform, and having returned Dr. Reid of his
trip to Wshington, the Comission decided to make the necessary
experiments to prove that contagion couldn't be made by the clothes
and objects of the patients of Yellow Fever: and then, prove and
show, beyond doubt, that the sickness was only transmitted by the
mosquito, according with what for 19 years had been proclaimed by
the famous cuban doctor Carlos Finlay.
Dr Carbonell

A far distant place, the San José Farm was selected for that pur-
pose and two barracks were built, Building No. 1 and Building No. 2,
to-gether both were named Camp Lazear, as a homage to the deceased
medical colleague. In building No. 1, the experiments were made to
demonstrate that contagion by the objects of the patients was not
possible; and in building No. 2, the inoculations by the mosquito
bites, were made.”
To here the article.

You all know that Mr. John F. Moran, the last of those who volun-
teered to be bitten by the mosquito, recently died at Havana.

It was in the house of this extraordinary man, an excellent friend
of mine, located in 25th St. between B and C, Vedado, where I had the
high honor of being introduced to Dr. Philip S. Hench and to his
lovely wife. Dr. Hench, to whom I had been writing, had come to Hava-
na with the idea of making a Cuban-American Monument to the conque-
rors of Yellow Fever and he had the initial offering of $10.000 to
be donated by the Mayo Clinic; he also told me that the medical doctors
of the United States would give a strong amount to build the monument.

A week or ten days after I had met Dr. Hench at Mr. Moran's house,
I was called by Dr. Hench who told me that he was to leave Havana
in about two days and that he was disappointed, because he had not
succeeded in getting an interview with the President, at that time
Dr. Ramón Grau San Martín.

Regretting the little attention paid to Dr. Hench, a medical doc-
tor of a Clinic that I had had the pleasure of visiting twice and where
I have friends that had kindly cumplimented me, I remembered that I
told him; “Well, you couldn't see the President, and it would be very
difficult for me to obtain an appointment with him in such a short
time, but to-night you'll see the Vice-President”.

After a telephone call to my distinguished friend Mr. Raúl de
Cárdenas and having had dinner in a Prado St. restaurant, Dr. Hench,
his wife and I were kindly received, as it is his custom, by Mr.
Raúl de Cárdenas, at that time Vice-President of the Republic, who
paid great attention to Dr. Hench and promised his full cooperation
to the fulfillment of his plans.
Dr Carbonell

Next day, Dr. Hench and I visited my old friend Engineer Honorato
Colete, here with us, atc the Ministry of Public Works and since that
moment we have had the pleasure help of so valuable an ally in that
Ministry. With Mr. Colete we visited the Assistant Secretary, and
in his office, Dr. Hench, putting his hand in his pocket pretended
to give to Mr. Colete or to me $1.000 to avoid the wreck of the caseta
or as he said “to prevent that the patient die while we are discussing
the methode to save him”.

Colete and I did not accept the generous offering, but we promised
Dr. Hench all the aid that we could give. We have been doing so.

It is on account of this, that we are taking advantage of the
brilliant oportunity presented to us by the Lions Club of Havana, to
recall to everybody that it was Dr. Hench who localized the caseta
of Camp Lazear and, further more, who made several trips to Cuba
with the intention of building that monument.
But...Who is this Dr. Hench to whom we have been referring so often?

At that time he was a studious and distinguished medical doctor
of one of the most famous Clinics in the world and the same time,
a man as non-affected as he is agreable.

But, two, three, four years passed and to-day, Dr. Philip S. Hench
to the benefit of humanity and satisfaction of those that consider
ourselves his friends, is the Nobel Prize of Medicine 1950, to-gether
-4-
with Dr. Edward C. Kendall, also a member of that Mayo Clinic, so
admired and loved by so many of us, for having made the discovery
and firsts works with the Cortisone, that misterious hormone of the
Supra-renal gland, called by many, the most important medical disco-
very in the last years.
Gentlemen:

Realizing the principal part had by a scientist of
so great personality and actuality, as Dr. Philip S. Hench has, in
the discovery and location of the caseta at Camp Lazear, I am sure
that, not only the Minister of Public Health, but the Lion's Club
of Havana will back Dr. Hench's initiative and that he should be an
honor guest of the cuban government, for the inauguration of the
monument, to whose construction he has worked so much in this country
in spite of the tremendous distance that separates him, from his
brilliant activities and from his home.
